page.title: 10THE LIFEBOAT SERVICE, RHYL
page.content: The Rhyl lifeboat service started in 1852. The lifeboat station was originally built at the Foryd harbour but the boat would not go under the bridge at high tide and it was difficult to launch at low tide. Thus, in 1894 it was moved to its present position halfway along the promenade. The Rhyl boat covers an area from the Point of Ayr to Llandulas. The present boat, installed in 1969, was bought with a Â£37,000 legacy from Miss Watt in memory of her parents, Harold and Lilian. Its name "Harlil" comes from the first three letters of each of their names. It is an Oakley self-righting boat which can automatically right itself in 6 seconds. It travels 165 miles on a full tank of fuel and its speed is about 8 knots. A more modern boat will be installed in 1989.
